Fig. 1 Equilibrium constant K p (1) and equilibrium CO2 conversion at CO2:H2 molar ratio of 1:1 (2) and 1:4 (3) for RWGS reaction as a function of temperature (adapted from [9], for details see the Supporting Information). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of temperature on CO2 conversion for the RWGS reaction over H3PMo12O40 supported on SiO2, TiO2, γ-Al2O3 and CeO2 (30 % HPA loading) and over 29 %MoO3/SiO2: 0.20 g catalyst pretreated at reaction temperature in H2 flow for 1 h, CO2:H2 = 1:1, 20 ml min−1 flow rate, GHSV = 6000 ml g−1h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Time course for RWGS reaction over 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalyst (0.20 g), 450 °C, CO2:H2 = 1:1, 20 ml min−1 flow rate, GHSV = 6000 ml g−1h−1, 25 h TOS. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 DRIFT spectra of fresh catalysts: bulk H3PMo12O40 (1), 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 (2), 30 %H3PMo12O40/CeO2 (3), 30 %H3PMo12O40/TiO2 (4), 29 %MoO3/SiO2 prepared from (NH4)6Mo7O24 (5), 30 %H3PMo12O40/Al2O3 (6). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 DRIFT spectra of fresh bulk H3PMo12O40 (1), fresh 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 (2), spent 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 (3) and spent bulk H3PMo12O40 (4) after RWGS at 450 °C and CO2:H2 = 1:1. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XRD of H3PMo12O40 catalysts: (1) fresh bulk H3PMo12O40, (2) spent bulk H3PMo12O40, (3) fresh 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and (4) spent 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2; fresh catalysts air-calcined at 300 °C, spent catalysts after RWGS reaction at 450 °C, CO2:H2 = 1:1. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR of 29 %MoO3/SiO2 normalised to Mo loading: (1) fresh catalyst, (2) spent catalyst after RWGS at 450 °C, CO2:H2 = 1:1, 1 h TOS, (3) catalyst pretreated in H2 flow (20 ml min−1) for 1 h and (4) catalyst after three RWGS looping cycles at 450 °C discussed below (Fig. 9). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XRD patterns of fresh and spent molybdenum catalysts (finely ground physical mixtures of Mo metal powder, MoO2, MoO3 and (NH4)6Mo7O24∙4 H2O with SiO2, all containing 38 wt% of Mo): (1) Mo metal powder (38:62 w/w Mo+SiO2 mixture), (2) fresh 51:49 w/w MoO2+SiO2 mixture (237 nm MoO2 particle size), (3) spent 51:49 w/w MoO2+SiO2 mixture (213 nm MoO2 particle size), (4) fresh 57:43 w/w MoO3+SiO2 mixture, (5) spent 57:43 w/w MoO3+SiO2 mixture showing MoO2 pattern (62 nm MoO2 particle size), (6) fresh 66:34 w/w (NH4)6Mo7O24+SiO2 mixture, and (7) spent 66:34 w/w (NH4)6Mo7O24+SiO2 mixture showing MoO2 pattern (91 nm MoO2 particle size). The spent catalysts were after RWGS reaction at 450 °C, CO2:H2 = 1:1, GHSV = 12000 ml g−1h−1 and 2 h TOS (Table 7). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Chemical looping (A) and carbon balance (B) for RWGS reaction on 29 %MoO3/SiO2 (0.40 g) at 450 °C: catalyst reduction step in H2 flow (20 ml min−1, 1 h) followed by 15 min He purge and CO2 reaction step in N2:CO2:He (2:23:75 mol/mol) gas flow (20 min min−1). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 HAADF-STEM images of fresh and spent 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and 29 %MoO3/SiO2 catalysts displaying MoOx particles as bright spots: (a) fresh and (b) spent 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalyst, (c) fresh and (d) spent 29 %MoO3/SiO2 catalyst. Fresh catalysts after pretreatment under H2 flow at 450 °C for 1 h; spent catalysts after RWGS reaction at 450 °C, CO2:H2 = 1:1, GHSV = 6000 ml g−1h−1, 2 h TOS. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 HAADF-STEM images of fresh (top) and spent (bottom) 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalysts and the corresponding STEM-EDX elemental maps showing the spatial distribution of Mo (green) and P (red) in the samples. Box 551, Saudi Arabi c The University of Liverpool, Albert Crewe Centre for Electron Microscopy, Liverpool L69 3GL, UK The University of Liverpool, Albert Crewe Centre for Electron Microscopy Liverpool L69 3GL UK The University of Liverpool, Albert Crewe Centre for Electron Microscopy, Liverpool L69 3GL ⁎ Corresponding author. The reverse water gas shift (RWGS) was studied in the presence of catalysts based on Keggin-type polyoxometalates (POMs) such as heteropoly acids H3PMo12O40 and H3PW12O40 and their Co(II) and Ni(II) salts. Under reaction conditions, molybdenum POMs decomposed to form Mo oxide species, which exhibited high activity, selectivity and resistance to deactivation in the RWGS reaction. The catalysts formed from H3PMo12O40 supported on SiO2, TiO2 and γ-Al2O3 produced CO with 100 % selectivity at 31–33 % CO2 conversion at 600 °C and a CO2:H2 molar ratio of 1:1 (cf. 39 % equilibrium conversion). H3PMo12O40/SiO2 was more active than MoO3/SiO2 with the same Mo loading, revealing a phosphorus enhancement effect on the activity of molybdenum species. This effect can be attributed to the influence of phosphate on the dispersion of the Mo oxide active phase. This is supported by STEM, which shows different morphologies of Mo oxide species in H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 catalysts. Chemical looping and H2-TPR of fresh and spent Mo catalysts show that the reaction occurs through the redox mechanism involving the reduction of Mo(VI) oxide species to Mo(IV) with H2, followed by reoxidation of Mo(IV) with CO2 to form CO (reverse Mars–van Krevelen mechanism). Contrary to the Mo catalysts, tungsten POMs, exhibited no RWGS activity, which can be attributed to their resistance to reduction. Graphical Abstract Keywords RWGS reaction Carbon dioxide Carbon monoxide Polyoxometalates Molybdenum catalysts Reverse Mars–van Krevelen mechanism Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Reducing CO2 concentration in the atmosphere is a major challenge in the 21st century ([1–7] and references therein). Current approaches to this problem include capturing and storing CO2 [1,2] and converting CO2 to value-added products [3–7]. Of particular interest is converting CO2 to CO by reducing CO2 with sustainable H2 (Eq. (1)) known as the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction [4,8–13]. The CO thus obtained can be transformed through the well-established industrial syngas routes into various commodity chemicals and fuels [3–9]. (1) CO2 + H2 = CO + H2O (2) CO2 + 4H2 = CH4 + 2H2O RWGS is a reversible mildly endothermic reaction, ΔH 298 = 41 kJ mol−1, favoured at high temperatures [8,9]. The equilibrium conversion of CO2 increases with increasing reaction temperature ( Fig. 1). The mechanism of this reaction is still debated; redox and associative mechanisms have been proposed [5,6,11]. The RWGS reaction competes with CO2 methanation (Eq. (2)), which is an exothermic reaction, ΔH 298 = –165 kJ mol−1, dominating at low temperatures [8,9]. Many RWGS and CO2 methanation catalysts have been reported, mostly based on metals and metal oxides ([3–17] and references therein). It has been demonstrated that Mo(VI) oxide catalysts are promising for the RWGS reaction due to their high selectivity to CO and resistance to deactivation [12–15]. However, these catalysts have a relatively low activity hence a moderate CO2 conversion. Previous studies suggest that Mo(VI) is reduced to Mo(IV) during the RWGS reaction [13]. Modifying supported Mo(VI) oxide catalysts with Cu, Ni and Pt metal additives facilitating Mo(VI) reduction has been found to increase catalyst activity [12,13,15]. However, further improvement of catalyst activity and understanding of reaction mechanism is desired. This work investigates the RWGS reaction in the presence of polyoxometalates (POMs) as catalysts. Typically, POMs comprise Mo(VI) and W(VI) as addenda atoms [18–20]. Here, commercially available Keggin-type heteropoly acids (HPAs) H3PMo12O40 and H3PW12O40 with P5+ as the central atom were studied as the RWGS catalysts. In addition, Co(II) and Ni(II) salts of these HPAs were also used. As these POMs have a low surface area [19,20], research was mainly focussed on supported HPAs, with SiO2, γ-Al2O3, TiO2 and CeO2 as the catalyst support. Previously, these catalysts have been reported to have high hydrodesulfurization activity [21]. Here, we demonstrate that supported Mo catalysts prepared from H3PMo12O40 have high activity, 100 % CO selectivity and resistance to deactivation in the RWGS reaction. Chemical looping, STEM-EDX, DRIFT spectroscopy, H2-TPR and XRD analysis of fresh and spent catalysts provide new insight into the reaction mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials Phosphomolybdic and phosphotungstic acid hydrates H3PMo12O40∙nH2O and H3PW12O40∙nH2O, (NH4)6Mo7O24∙4 H2O, MoO3, MoO2, Mo metal powder, Ni(NO3)2∙6 H2O, Co(NO3)2∙6 H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O were from Sigma-Aldrich. Catalyst supports Aerosil 300 silica (S BET = 300 m2g−1), P25 titania (anatase/rutile = 3:1, S BET = 51 m2g−1) and Aluminiumoxid C γ-alumina (S BET = 120 m2g−1) were from Degussa. CeO2 (S BET = 85 m2g−1) was prepared in-house by calcining Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O in air at 500 °C for 3 h and 5 °C min−1 temperature ramp rate [22]. The resulting yellow powder was ground to 90–180 μm particle size and stored in a desiccator. High-purity CO2 (>99.99 %) and H2 (99.99 %) were supplied by the British Oxygen Company. 2.2 Preparation of RWGS catalysts Bulk Ni(II) and Co(II) salts Ni1.5PM12O40 and Co1.5PM12O40, where M = Mo(VI) or W(VI), were prepared as described previously [21] by dissolving the HPA in a minimum amount of deionised water at room temperature followed by adding the required amount of Co(NO3)2 or Ni(NO3)2 with stirring. Excess water was distilled off using a rotary evaporator. The resulting residue was dried at 100 °C and calcined in air at 300 °C for 2 h at a temperature ramp rate of 5 °C min−1. Supported Mo and W catalysts were prepared by impregnating support (SiO2, γ-Al2O3, TiO2 and CeO2) with Mo or W precursor from an aqueous solution as described previously [21] at a precursor loading of 30 % by weight unless stated otherwise. As the precursors, H3PM12O40, Ni1.5PM12O40, Co1.5PM12O40 and (NH4)6Mo7O24 were used. The supported catalysts were calcined in air at 300 °C/2 h/5 °C min−1 , then ground to 90–180 μm particle size and stored in a desiccator. As shown by DRIFT spectroscopy, in the catalysts thus prepared, the Keggin structure of [PMo12O40]3- and [PW12O40]3- polyanions was intact (see below). From TGA, ammonium heptamolybdate, (NH4)6Mo7O24, decomposed after the calcination at 300 °C to form MoO3 in the supported catalysts (Fig. S1 in the Supporting Information). Mo and W loading was confirmed by ICP−OES analysis. Fine physical mixtures of Mo metal powder, MoO2, MoO3, (NH4)6Mo7O24∙4 H2O and H3PMo12O40 with SiO2, all containing 38 wt% of Mo, were prepared by grinding the molybdenum compounds with Aerosil 300 silica. Information about the texture of the prepared catalysts is given in Table 1. 2.3 Techniques Catalyst surface area, pore volume and pore size were determined on a Micromeritics 3Flex instrument by measuring nitrogen adsorption at –196 °C. Before measurement, the catalysts were pretreated at 220 °C for 1 h in a vacuum. Diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared (DRIFT) spectra of catalysts were recorded on a Nicolet Nexus FTIR spectrometer using powdered catalyst mixtures with KBr against the KBr background. XRD (powder X-ray diffraction) of catalysts was recorded on a Bruker D8 Discover diffractometer using monochromatic CuKα radiation (λ = 1.541 Å) in a 2θ range of 5–80°. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on a spherical aberration-corrected JEOL 2100 F microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping was performed using a JEOL Silicon Drift Detector DrySD100GV with a solid angle of up to 0.98 steradians from a detection area of 100 mm2. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of catalysts was carried out on a Micromeritics TPD/TPR 2900 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Catalyst samples (20–40 mg) were heated up to 950 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 in an H2–N2 (5:95) gas flow (35 ml min−1). For quantitative analysis, H2-TPR was calibrated using Ag2O. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TA TGA 55 thermal analyser. Mo and W content in catalysts was determined using ICP−OES (inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy) analysis on a Spectro Ciros ICP−OES instrument; catalyst samples were digested by boiling in 15 % aqueous KOH. The carbon content in spent catalysts was determined by combustion chemical analysis. 2.4 Catalyst testing The RWGS reaction was carried out at 400–600 °C under ambient pressure in a quartz fixed-bed tubular reactor of 9 mm internal diameter with online GC analysis (Agilent 8860 GC System with a thermal conductivity detector and two packed columns Porapack Q (2 mm × 1.5 m) and Molsieve 5 A (2 mm × 1.5 m) fitted in sequence). Fig. S2–S4 in the Supporting Information represent the reactor setup and GC analysis. The catalyst (0.20 g, 90–180 μm particle size unless stated otherwise) was placed on a quartz wool plug within the reactor. The reaction temperature was controlled by a Eurotherm controller with a thermocouple placed at the top of the catalyst bed. Before the reaction, the catalyst was pretreated at the reaction temperature for 1 h in H2 flow (20 ml min−1). Then the gas mixture containing N2 (GC internal standard), CO2, H2 and He (carrier gas) was fed to the reactor at a flow rate of 20 ml min−1 controlled by Brooks mass flow controllers. The CO2:H2 molar ratio in the gas feed was 1:1 or 1:4, with the gas feed N2:CO2:H2:He molar composition of 1.2:11.9:11.9:75.0 and 0.96:4.81:19.2:75.0, respectively. The space velocity, GHSV, was 6000 ml g−1h−1 unless stated otherwise. From online GC analysis, CO2 conversion and CO and CH4 selectivity were determined. The catalysts exhibited stable performance without deactivation, with a steady state reached before the first sampling of the reaction mixture. The mean absolute percentage error in CO2 conversion was ≤ 5 %, and the carbon balance was maintained within 98–100 % unless stated otherwise. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst activity in RWGS reaction Generally, CO2 hydrogenation catalysts are tested at a CO2:H2 molar ratio of 1:1 (RWGS stoichiometry, Eq. (1)) or 1:4 (methanation stoichiometry, Eq. (2)). Table 2 shows the results of initial catalyst testing at CO2:H2 = 1:4, 450 °C and 3 h time on stream (TOS) to identify more selective RWGS catalysts. All Mo catalysts, bulk and supported, exhibited RWGS activity at a CO2 conversion rate of 24–35 %. At such conditions, the equilibrium conversion of CO2 is 49 % (Fig. 1) [9]. The selectivity to CO was 100 %, except for Ni catalysts, which are known for their high methanation activity [12,16,17]. The Ni catalysts gave 6–13 % of methane and 87–94 % of CO at a 30–32 % CO2 conversion. With bulk and alumina-supported Ni(II) and Co(II) salts of H3PMo12O40, CO2 conversion did not exceed that for the alumina-supported parent acid H3PMo12O40 (all at 30 % POM loading), which shows that the presence of Ni and Co in these catalysts did not enhance their activity compared to H3PMo12O40. A 3:7 w/w physical mixture of bulk H3PMo12O40 and γ-Al2O3 gave a slightly lower CO2 conversion of 24 % compared to 30 %H3PMo12O40/Al2O3 (31 % conversion). Silica-supported H3PMo12O40 showed the highest activity at 35 % CO2 conversion and 100 % CO selectivity, with methanol selectivity ≤ 0.01 % (from GC-FID analysis). In contrast to Mo catalysts, the catalysts prepared from tungsten POMs (H3PW12O40 and its Ni(II) and Co(II) salts) showed no RWGS activity (Table 2). Possible reasons for this are discussed below. Next, we looked at the RWGS performance of supported Mo catalysts at 450 °C and stoichiometric molar ratio CO2:H2 = 1:1. Table 3 shows the effect of Mo precursor (H3PMo12O40 and (NH4)6Mo7O24) and catalyst support (SiO2, γ-Al2O3, TiO2 and CeO2) on the performance of Mo catalysts in RWGS reaction at the same Mo loading of 29 % based on MoO3 (19 % based on Mo). As can be seen, H3PMo12O40 catalysts supported on alumina, titania and silica exhibited a higher activity at 13–17 % CO2 conversion and 100 % CO selectivity (cf. 27 % equilibrium conversion, Fig. 1 [9]) and exceeded the activity of H3PMo12O40/CeO2. The latter was unexpected since CeO2 had been found beneficial in other RWGS catalysts [11]. H3PMo12O40/SiO2 showed the highest activity at 17.1 % CO2 conversion. Support had a relatively weak effect on the activity, which can be explained by the high loading of H3PMo12O40 (30 %). Nevertheless, H3PMo12O40/Al2O3 showed a lower activity than H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and H3PMo12O40/TiO2. This can be explained by stronger interaction of HPA with alumina support, leading to the formation of Al3+ salts of HPA [20]. Neat SiO2, TiO2 and Al2O3 supports had no activity at 450 °C. CeO2 has been reported to have a low RWGS activity below 500 °C [23,24]. MoO3/SiO2 prepared from (NH4)6Mo7O24 with similar Mo loading showed lower activity than H3PMo12O40/SiO2 at these conditions (Table 3). This points to an enhancement effect of phosphorus on the catalyst activity. This effect is discussed in more detail below. Molybdenum phosphide has been reported as the catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation [25], including RWGS reaction [26,27]. Fig. 2 shows the effect of temperature on CO2 conversion over H3PMo12O40 supported on SiO2, TiO2, γ-Al2O3 and CeO2 (30 % HPA loading) and over 29 %MoO3/SiO2 within 400–600 °C range. For the more active HPA catalysts supported on SiO2, TiO2 and γ-Al2O3, the conversion of CO2 increases from 6–8 to 31–33 % at GHSV = 6000 ml g−1h−1 (cf. the equilibrium conversion of 39 % at 600 °C). The slope of the conversion plots decreases monotonically with reaction temperature rather than following an S-shaped trend. This can be attributed to the agglomeration of the molybdenum active phase as the temperature increases (see below). Diffusion limitations as a possible cause of such behaviour can be ruled out because no effect of catalyst particle size on the reaction rate at 450–600 °C was observed (Table S2). Weisz-Prater analysis further strengthened this conclusion (see the Supporting Information): the Weisz-Prater criterion estimated to be C WP < < 1 at 600 o,C, indicating no internal diffusion limitation in this system. As seen in Fig. 2, HPA/SiO2 outperformed all catalysts at 450–550 °C, whereas at 600 °C all catalysts, except HPA/CeO2, showed close activities. Also, no phosphorus enhancement was observed at 600 °C (cf. HPA/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 at 600 °C). This can be attributed to the loss of phosphorus (P2O5 sublimation) and agglomeration of Mo oxide species at this temperature. The latter is supported by STEM showing agglomerates of Mo oxide > 10 nm in size in spent 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 after the RWGS reaction at 600 °C (Fig. S6) (cf. 1.7 nm MoOx species in spent 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 after the RWGS reaction at 450 °C, Sect. 3.4 below). STEM-EDX mapping detected only traces of phosphorus present in this sample at the EDX detection limit. The apparent activation energy E a was calculated within 400–450 °C temperature range to be 66, 63, 61 and 54 kJ mol−1 for H3PMo12O40 supported on SiO2, TiO2, CeO2 and γ-Al2O3, respectively; for 29 %MoO3/SiO2, E a = 54 kJ mol−1 (the Arrhenius plots are shown in Fig. S5). CO2 conversion over H3PMo12O40/SiO2 increased with increasing H3PMo12O40 loading at constant catalyst weight, reaching 17.1 % at 30–40 % HPA loading, then slightly decreased with increasing the HPA loading further ( Table 4). Bulk H3PMo12O40 gave 14.6 % CO2 conversion. 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 exhibited good performance stability; there was no decline in CO2 conversion and CO selectivity in the RWGS reaction during 25 h time on stream ( Fig. 3). 3.2 Catalyst characterisation The above results demonstrate the high RWGS activity of H3PMo12O40/SiO2 (Fig. 2). Silica is the most used support in HPA catalysts due to its inertness toward HPA and availability in a broad textural variety [20]. Further, H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalysts were characterized to gain insight into the reaction mechanism. The catalyst formulations shown in Tables 1–4 represent the composition of fresh catalysts as prepared. True catalysts form in the reaction course and may have a different composition. It was noted that fresh Mo catalysts calcined at 300 °C were pale, whereas the catalysts pretreated at 450 °C under H2 flow and spent catalysts after the RWGS reaction all turned black. From combustion chemical analysis, the amount of carbon in spent catalysts was negligible (0.1–0.3 wt%, Table S3). Therefore, the catalyst colour indicates the change in the chemical composition of catalysts during the RWGS reaction. Catalyst evolution during the RWGS reaction was monitored using DRIFT spectroscopy. DRIFT spectra of fresh Mo catalysts prepared from H3PMo12O40 and (NH4)6Mo7O24 and the spectrum of bulk heteropoly acid H3PMo12O40 are shown in Fig. 4. The bulk H3PMo12O40 exhibits the well-known spectrum of the Keggin polyanion with four characteristic IR bands in the range of 700–1100 cm−1. These include the bands at 793 cm−1 (Mo–O–Mo edge-sharing), 871 cm−1 (Mo–O–Mo corner-sharing), 964 cm−1 (MoO) and 1066 cm−1 (P–O) [18]. These bans are present in the DRIFT spectra of supported H3PMo12O40 catalysts, with some bands obscured by IR bands of support (DRIFT spectra of supports are shown in Fig. S7). Thus, H3PMo12O40/CeO2 shows all four characteristic Keggin bands practically unaffected by support. In the spectrum of H3PMo12O40/TiO2 all bands are seen except the band at 793 cm−1 hidden by support. H3PMo12O40/Al2O3 exhibits two Keggin bands at 964 and 1066 cm−1, with the other two concealed by support. H3PMo12O40/SiO2 shows the bands at 871 and 964 cm−1, whereas the band at 1066 cm−1 is completely obscured, and the band at 793 cm−1 is partially hidden by silica. Nevertheless, despite the interference with support, these spectra show that all fresh H3PMo12O40 catalysts, air-calcined at 300 °C, retain the Keggin structure. Contrarily, (NH4)6Mo7O24 decomposed on the silica surface to form MoO3 upon calcination at 300 °C, as confirmed by TGA (Fig. S1). Fig. 5. shows the DRIFT spectra of fresh and spent bulk H3PMo12O40 and supported 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalysts. The spent catalysts were taken after the RWGS reaction at 450 °C and CO2:H2 = 1:1. The spectra for bulk H3PMo12O40 demonstrate the loss of the Keggin structure after the reaction. This can be attributed to the reduction of Mo(VI) to Mo(IV) in the reaction course (see below). The weak peak at 960 cm−1 in the spectrum of spent bulk H3PMo12O40 catalyst can be assigned to MoO vibration in Mo(IV) oxide. The same conclusion can be made for the H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalyst, although this is less clear from the spectra in Fig. 5 due to the interference with the silica support. The loss of Mo–O–Mo band at 871 cm−1 indicates the decomposition of the Keggin structure in the spent H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalyst. The loss of Keggin structure during the RWGS reaction was also observed for bulk Co1.5PMo12O40 salt (Fig. S8). Fresh bulk H3PMo12O40 and fresh Co1.5PMo12O40 exhibit similar DRIFT spectra, confirming that fresh Co1.5PMo12O40 catalyst retained the Keggin structure. However, the Keggin structure was lost after heating Co1.5PMo12O40 at 350 and 400 °C in an H2 flow and was completely lost in the spent Co1.5PMo12O40 catalyst after the RWGS reaction at 450 °C and CO2:H2 = 1:4 (Fig. S8). This shows that Mo(VI) polyoxometalates are only precursors of RWGS catalysts; the true catalysts are formed in situ during thermal pretreatment of the POM precursors under H2 flow. Fig. S9 shows the DRIFT spectra of bulk Co1.5PW12O40, fresh and thermally pretreated in an H2 flow, together with the spectrum of bulk H3PW12O40. The latter, like H3PMo12O40, exhibits the characteristic IR bands of the Keggin structure at 804 cm−1 (W–O–W edge-sharing), 891 cm−1 (W–O–W corner-sharing), 984 cm−1 (WO) and 1080 cm−1 (P–O) [18]. As seen in Fig. S9, all these bands are present in the spectrum of the fresh Co1.5PW12O40 catalyst, thus confirming retaining the Keggin structure. Moreover, in contrast to Co1.5PMo12O40, the Keggin structure was retained after heating Co1.5PW12O40 at 350 and 400 °C in H2. This agrees with the much higher stability of [PW12O40]3- to the reduction compared to [PMo12O40]3- as expected from their reduction potentials (0.15 V and 0.65 V vs. SHE, respectively [20]). From these results, the lack of RWGS activity of tungsten POMs can be attributed to their resistance to reduction to form catalytically active species. XRD patterns of fresh and spent H3PMo12O40 catalysts are presented in Fig. 6. The fresh bulk H3PMo12O40 air-calcined at 300 °C exhibited the known pattern of crystalline phosphomolybdic acid [28]. In contrast, the spent catalyst after the RWGS reaction at 450 °C was amorphous. The absence of XRD peaks may indicate small particles or a non-crystalline Mo structure. 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2, both fresh and spent catalysts, were amorphous, and so were fresh and spent 29 %MoO3/SiO2 catalysts (not shown). To gain insight into the nature of active Mo species, we performed H2-TPR on fresh and spent Mo catalysts. The H2-TPR on spent catalysts was carried out in situ after the RWGS reaction to prevent the catalysts from re-oxidation. First, the catalyst (20–40 mg) was pretreated in a TPR sample tube at 450 °C/1 h in H2 flow (35 ml min−1), then the RWGS reaction was carried out at 450 °C and CO2:H2 = 1:1 for 1 h. After that, the sample tube was cooled to room temperature under CO2-H2 (1:1) flow, and then the H2-TPR was performed up to 950 °C (10 °C min−1 ramp rate) using an H2-N2 (5:95) gas mixture at a flow rate of 35 ml min−1. H2-TPR traces are shown in Fig. 7 and S10–S12, and their quantification is in Table 5 for fresh catalysts and Table 6 for spent catalysts. Fig. 7 shows the H2-TPR for the fresh and spent 29 %MoO3/SiO2 catalyst prepared using ammonium heptamolybdate as a Mo precursor. The fresh catalyst (38.3 mg, 0.077 mmol Mo(VI)) exhibited a typical H2-TPR of MoO3. In agreement with previous reports [29–32], it includes two reduction peaks: Mo(VI) to Mo(IV) at 554 °C followed by Mo(IV) to Mo(0) at 822 °C. The total amount of H2 consumed for Mo(VI) to Mo(0) reduction was 0.28 mmol, which is close to the expected 0.23 mmol H2, with the molar ratio of H2 consumption for Mo(VI)/Mo(IV) and Mo(IV)/Mo(0) reduction steps of 1:1.7 (Table 5), close to the expected ratio of 1:2. The spent catalyst (34.0 mg) shows only Mo(IV)/Mo(0) reduction at 780 °C. The low-temperature shift of this peak may be due to structural changes in the Mo oxide phase during the reaction. Assuming that the spent catalyst contained only Mo(IV) (0.069 mmol), the amount of H2 consumed for the Mo(IV)/Mo(0) reduction would be 0.14 mmol (Table 6). The experimental H2 consumption (0.13 mmol) was in perfect agreement with the expected value, thus confirming the quantitative reduction of Mo(VI) to Mo(IV) in the course of the RWGS reaction on 29 %MoO3/SiO2. As seen in Fig. 7, the Mo(IV) oxide forms already after catalyst pretreatment in H2 at 450 °C (H2-TPR trace (3)). This agrees with [13] suggesting the reduction of Mo(VI) to Mo(IV) in MoO3/FAU zeolite RWGS catalyst. Fig. S10, S11 and S12 present the H2-TPR results for fresh and spent 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2, 30 %H3PMo12O40/Al2O3 and 30 %H3PMo12O40/TiO2 catalysts. These results are close to those for 29 %MoO3/SiO2. In all cases, the fresh catalysts exhibited two reduction peaks, Mo(VI)/Mo(IV) and Mo(IV)/Mo(0), whereas the spent catalysts showed one reduction peak attributed to the reduction of Mo(IV) to Mo(0). However, quantitative aspects of the H2-TPR for the supported H3PMo12O40 catalysts are less certain compared to MoO3/SiO2. Particularly, this is apparent for the spent H3PMo12O40 catalysts supported on Al2O3 and SiO2 that have a larger surface area (Table 6). In these cases, the amount of H2 consumed was 5-fold lower than expected. This can be explained by strong interaction between H3PMo12O40 and support (e.g., formation of Al(III) molybdate) leading to the formation of finely dispersed Mo species that could reduce to Mo(0) during the RWGS reaction. Another complication could be the formation of mixed-valence Mo(VI)/Mo(V) species upon reduction of H3PMo12O40 [33] analogous to molybdenum bronze [34]. The active role of the Mo(IV) species was further supported by testing the RWGS activity of physically mixed molybdenum catalysts with SiO2 ( Table 7) complemented by XRD analysis of the phase composition of fresh and spent catalysts. The mixed catalysts were prepared by grinding commercial molybdenum compounds (H3PMo12O40, (NH4)6Mo7O24, MoO3, MoO2 and Mo metal powder) with Aerosil 300 silica; all the catalysts had the same Mo content of 38 wt%. As seen, all these catalysts exhibited 100 % CO selectivity. The H3PMo12O40 catalyst showed the highest activity (11.9 % CO2 conversion) at the specified reaction conditions. The MoO3 catalysts prepared from Mo(VI) oxide and molybdenum heptamolybdate showed the same activity (9.7 % conversion), somewhat lower than H3PMo12O40. This confirms the phosphorus enhancement of RWGS activity noted above. The MoO2 catalyst prepared from commercial MoO2 was expected to have a similar activity to MoO3, however, its activity was significantly lower (1.6 % conversion). This could be due to the large particle size of MoO2 (see the XRD data below). Mo metal exhibited negligible activity at ∼1 % CO2 conversion. Importantly, the H3PMo12O40 and MoO3 catalysts pretreated in an N2 flow instead of H2 flow showed no RWGS activity, which supports the reduction of Mo(VI) during the reaction. The phase composition of fresh and spent physically mixed molybdenum catalysts was analysed using XRD ( Fig. 8). The spent catalysts were after RWGS reaction at 450 °C, CO2:H2 = 1:1, GHSV = 12000 ml g−1h−1 and 2 h TOS (Table 7). The fresh H3PMo12O40+SiO2 catalyst exhibited the pattern of crystalline phosphomolybdic acid [28] shown in Fig. 6, whereas the spent catalyst was amorphous. The XRD for other catalysts is presented in Fig. 8. Fresh Mo+SiO2, MoO2+SiO2, MoO3+SiO2 and (NH4)6Mo7O24+SiO2 exhibited the well-documented patterns of Mo metal (JCPDS 01–1208), MoO2 (JCPDS 32–0671), MoO3 (JCPDS 05–0506) and (NH4)6Mo7O24∙4 H2O (JCPDS 11–0071), respectively. The spent Mo metal catalyst exhibited the same XRD pattern as the fresh one (pattern 1). Likewise, both fresh and spent MoO2 catalysts showed the same pattern of MoO2 (cf. patterns 2 and 3). Importantly, the spent MoO3 catalysts prepared either from genuine MoO3 or from (NH4)6Mo7O24 exhibited the MoO2 pattern, without a trace of Mo metal (cf. patterns 4 and 5, 6 and 7). This demonstrates that MoO3 is reduced to MoO2 during the RWGS reaction and suggests that MoO2 is likely the active phase in these systems. The MoO2 particle size was estimated from the Scherrer equation. In the mixed MoO2+SiO2 catalyst prepared from commercial MoO2, it was greater (237 nm in fresh and 213 nm in spent catalyst) than in spent MoO3+SiO2 (62 nm) and (NH4)6Mo7O24+SiO2 (91 nm) catalysts. This may be the reason for the lower activity of MoO2+SiO2 compared to the MoO3+SiO2 and (NH4)6Mo7O24+SiO2 catalysts (Table 7). 3.3 Chemical looping Further insight into the reaction mechanism was gained using RWGS looping experiments involving consecutive steps of catalyst reduction with H2 followed by oxidation with CO2 producing CO. Fig. 9A shows three looping cycles over 29 %MoO3/SiO2 at 450 °C. Sampling began 2 min after the start of feeding CO2 – the time required for the CO2 to reach the catalyst bed. No CO was formed without catalyst pre-reduction by H2. Fig. 9B shows the reaction carbon balance. As seen, it generally maintained at 98–100 %, except at the beginning of the CO2 reaction step, when it dropped to 30–80 % due to CO2 adsorption on the catalyst, with the drop decreasing in each consecutive cycle, as expected for a strong CO2 adsorption. The CO2 reaction steps produced CO in a 5 % yield, with the amount of Mo(VI) formed 11 % of the total Mo loading in the catalyst. After the third cycle, H2-TPR was performed on the catalyst (Fig. 7, trace 4). A large Mo(IV) to Mo(0) reduction peak at 764 °C demonstrates that after the CO2 reaction step, the catalyst largely contained Mo(IV). A broad hump between 300–400 °C can be attributed semi-quantitatively to Mo(VI) produced by the oxidation of Mo(IV) with CO2. This Mo(VI) is likely to be finely distributed at the catalyst surface, which could cause the shift of the Mo(VI) to Mo(IV) reduction temperature down to 300–400 °C. Fig. S13A shows two RWGS looping cycles over 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 at the same conditions. The results are close to those of the 29 %MoO3/SiO2 catalyst, except 30 %H3PMoO12O40/SiO2 produced higher CO yields in each cycle (∼9 %), which agrees with its higher activity. Another difference is a smaller drop in the carbon balance, down to 78–90 % (Fig. S13B). This is not unexpected since the HPA/SiO2 catalyst is more acidic than MoO3/SiO2 and, therefore, should adsorb less CO2. In this case, H2-TPR clearly shows two reduction peaks for Mo(VI) to Mo(IV) at 412 °C and Mo(IV) to Mo(0) at 670 °C (Fig. S14), with the reduction temperatures also shifted down compared to the fresh 30 %H3PMoO12O40/SiO2 catalyst (cf. Fig. S10). The chemical looping, complimented by H2-TPR and XRD, gives strong evidence for the RWGS reaction occurring via the redox mechanism on the catalysts formed from Mo(VI) oxide and POM ( Scheme 1). This mechanism involves the reduction of Mo(VI) to Mo(IV) with H2, forming an oxygen vacancy, followed by oxidation of Mo(IV) to Mo(VI) by CO2, refilling the oxygen vacancy to complete the catalytic cycle with CO formation (reverse Mars–van Krevelen mechanism [15,35]). 3.4 Phosphorus enhancement The phosphorus enhancement noted above was further investigated by testing the activity of silica-supported H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 catalysts modified by H3PO4. These catalysts were prepared by impregnating SiO2 with aqueous solutions of H3PMo12O40 and (NH4)6Mo7O24, respectively, to a Mo loading of 19 wt%, with H3PO4 added to the impregnating solution to a P:Mo atomic ratio of 1:12 – 1:3, followed by drying at 100 °C and air calcination at 300 °C. The results are presented in Table 8. It can be seen that H3PMo12O40/SiO2 (P:Mo = 1:12) exhibited a higher activity than MoO3/SiO2 without H3PO4 added (CO2 conversion of 14.1 and 12.6 %, respectively), thus confirming the phosphorus enhancement effect. However, the activity declined when the P:Mo ratio increased to 1:6 and 1:3. The phosphorus enhancement can be attributed to the influence of phosphate on the dispersion of the active Mo(IV) oxide phase formed from H3PMo12O40. It is conceivable that the reductive decomposition of the relatively stable and compact Keggin anion [PMo12O40]3- (1.2 nm in size [20]) during the RWGS reaction would form rather small Mo(IV) oxide species (whose composition is not known yet). On the other hand, the reductive decomposition of the less stable ammonium heptamolybdate gives larger MoO2 species (confirmed by XRD, Fig. 8). The addition of H3PO4 to (NH4)6Mo7O24 did not enhance catalyst activity (Table 8) as the Keggin POM did not form at such conditions. The addition of H3PO4 to H3PMo12O40 in an aqueous solution is known to degrade the 1:12 P-Mo Keggin anion to form less stable lacunary 1:11, 1:9 and 2:5 P-Mo polyanions [20]. This could lead to larger Mo(IV) oxide species in the H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalysts modified with H3PO4, which have a lower activity. STEM-EDX analysis demonstrated different morphologies of MoOx particles in H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 catalysts, providing insight into the phosphate enhancement effect. Fig. 10 shows the high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) images of fresh and spent 30 %H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and 29 %MoO3/SiO2 catalysts displaying MoOx particles as bright spots on the darker background: fresh catalysts after pretreatment under H2 flow at 450 °C for 1 h and spent catalysts after RWGS reaction at 450 °C, CO2:H2 = 1:1 and GHSV = 6000 ml g−1h−1. Two populations can be seen in these catalysts: small, almost spherical MoOx particles and agglomerates of a larger size. The fresh and spent H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalysts mostly contain small spherical MoOx particles of 2.1 nm average size in fresh and 1.7 nm in spent catalyst; their particle size distribution is presented in Fig. S15. Contrarily, the fresh and spent MoO3/SiO2 catalysts, that do not include phosphorus, mostly contain larger MoOx agglomerates. The energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopic analysis (EDX) shows that the H3PMo12O40/SiO2 catalysts contain both Mo and phosphorus ( Fig. 11). The Mo/P weight ratio (34 in fresh and 37 in spent catalyst) is close to that in H3PMo12O40 (37.2). EDX elemental mapping demonstrates that Mo and P maps cover the same areas of the catalysts, indicating an interaction between MoOx and P, which could explain the different morphology of H3PMo12O40 and MoO3-based catalysts. The MoOx species that originated from relatively stable spherical Keggin polyanions [PMo12O40]3- (1.2 nm in size [20]) form rather small spherical particles. Meanwhile, decomposition of the less stable ammonium heptamolybdate is more likely to produce MoOx agglomerates. 4 Conclusions In this work, we have investigated the RWGS reaction in the presence of catalysts based on Keggin-type polyoxometalates (POMs) supported on SiO2, γ-Al2O3, TiO2 and CeO2. The POMs include Keggin-type heteropoly acids H3PMo12O40 and H3PW12O40 and their Co(II) and Ni(II) salts. Under reaction conditions, molybdenum POMs decompose to form Mo oxide species, which exhibit high activity, selectivity, and resistance to deactivation in the RWGS reaction. Thus, H3PMo12O40-based catalysts supported on SiO2, TiO2 and γ-Al2O3 produce CO with 100 % selectivity at 31–33 % CO2 conversion at 600 °C and a CO2:H2 molar ratio of 1:1 (cf. 39 % equilibrium conversion). At 450–550 °C, H3PMo12O40/SiO2 is more active than MoO3/SiO2 with the same Mo loading, revealing the phosphorus enhancement effect on the activity of molybdenum species. This effect is attributed to the influence of phosphate on the dispersion of the Mo oxide active phase, which is supported by STEM showing different morphologies of Mo oxide species in H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 catalysts. The phosphorus enhancement effect was not observed at a higher temperature of 600 °C, as the H3PMo12O40-based catalysts and MoO3/SiO2 had the same activity. This may be due to phosphorus loss and Mo oxide agglomeration, as evidenced by STEM. Chemical looping and H2-TPR of fresh and spent Mo catalysts show that the reaction occurs through the reverse Mars–van Krevelen redox mechanism involving the reduction of Mo(VI) oxide species to Mo(IV) with H2 followed by reoxidation of Mo(IV) with CO2 to form CO. In contrast to Mo catalysts, the W catalysts prepared from tungsten POMs show no RWGS activity, which can be attributed to their resistance to reduction to form active species. coredata.dc:description: The reverse water gas shift (RWGS) was studied in the presence of catalysts based on Keggin-type polyoxometalates (POMs) such as heteropoly acids H3PMo12O40 and H3PW12O40 and their Co(II) and Ni(II) salts. Under reaction conditions, molybdenum POMs decomposed to form Mo oxide species, which exhibited high activity, selectivity and resistance to deactivation in the RWGS reaction. The catalysts formed from H3PMo12O40 supported on SiO2, TiO2 and γ-Al2O3 produced CO with 100 % selectivity at 31–33 % CO2 conversion at 600 °C and a CO2:H2 molar ratio of 1:1 (cf. 39 % equilibrium conversion). H3PMo12O40/SiO2 was more active than MoO3/SiO2 with the same Mo loading, revealing a phosphorus enhancement effect on the activity of molybdenum species. This effect can be attributed to the influence of phosphate on the dispersion of the Mo oxide active phase. This is supported by STEM, which shows different morphologies of Mo oxide species in H3PMo12O40/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 catalysts. Chemical looping and H2-TPR of fresh and spent Mo catalysts show that the reaction occurs through the redox mechanism involving the reduction of Mo(VI) oxide species to Mo(IV) with H2, followed by reoxidation of Mo(IV) with CO2 to form CO (reverse Mars–van Krevelen mechanism). Contrary to the Mo catalysts, tungsten POMs, exhibited no RWGS activity, which can be attributed to their resistance to reduction.
